section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build background, engage children with the theme song, and introduce the vocabulary (tiny, bud).
Begin Story Time by introducing the book Seed to Plant and asking, What are the parts of a plant?
Read for enjoyment and understanding, noticing vocabulary in context.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Engage in conversations with a variety of partners, taking turns listening and speaking.
Respond appropriately to spoken language.
Understand and use varied types of words.
Talk and share.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Participate in prereading and reading-related activities.
Describe the life cycles of different plants and animals; Understand differences between living and nonliving things.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Challenge students to classify objects as “living things” or “nonliving things.”
Through talking and sharing, guide students to understand the characteristics of living organisms like plants.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we help plants grow?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What book tells a story about a plant or animal growing up?
What could you use to make a plant costume?
How many seeds does it take to make three sunflower plants?
Draw or write a list of the parts of a plant.
Make a collage about plants.
What is the first sound in seed? What letter makes that sound?
Build something as tall as a sunflower.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder talk and share and introduce the vocabulary (share, faces).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to Seed to Plant.
Read closely to prompt and practice the Mind Builder.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Engage in conversations with a variety of partners, taking turns listening and speaking.
Respond appropriately to spoken language.
Understand and use varied types of words.
Talk and share
Make connections between situations.
Participate in pre-reading and reading-related activities.
Join two or more words to create a compound word.
Revise and edit group writing.
Describe the life cycle of different plants and animals.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Challenge students to connect pictures to the stages in a plant’s life cycle.
Guide students to understand that all plants have a life cycle.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we help plants grow?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Show me a picture of a baby plant in a book.
Act like you are planting seeds in a garden. Show me how to plant them.
How would you measure a sunflower’s height? Show me the tools you would use.
Make up a name for a flower that lives in water. Write or draw some details about this plant.
Use molding clay to make a flower seed and then a flower in bloom.
What if you change the beginning sound of seed? What other words could you make?
Show me how you could use these sticks to build a fence to keep plants safe.

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Seed to Plant by Lisa M. Herrington. Copyright © 2014 by Scholastic Inc. Published by Scholastic Inc. Clifford the Big Red DogTM illustration copyright © The Norman Bridwell Trust.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the comprehension skill Make Inferences and introduce vocabulary (seeds, stem).
Begin Story Time by revisiting Seed to Plant and asking the guiding question, What do the parts of a plant do?
Read interactively to make inferences.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Engage in conversations with a variety of partners, taking turns listening and speaking.
Respond appropriately to spoken language.
Understand and use a growing number of science words.
Understand and use some words or phrases in another language.
Talk and share
Make connections between situations.
Make inferences.
Revise and edit group writing.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Challenge students to identify, describe, and act out plant care activities.
Guide students to understand the connection between ideas in the book and the activity cards.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we help plants grow?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How is the plant in this book like the sunflower in Seed to Plant?
Pretend you want to grow the biggest pumpkin in the world. How would you do that?
Take one of each kind of seed and arrange them by size. Which is the smallest? the largest?
Write or draw what you like about plants.
What shapes do you need to make a plant? Show me how they go together.
How do weed and seed sound the same? Point to the letters they share.
Show me what materials you would use to build a garden.

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Seed to Plant by Lisa M. Herrington. Copyright © 2014 by Scholastic Inc. Published by Scholastic Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Chart of Big Ideas: Jack and the Beanstalk

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: In Circle Time, invite children to share what they have learned about our Earth, sing, and introduce the vocabulary (beanstalk, climbed).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts Jack and the Beanstalk and Seed to Plant .
Read and connect to this week’s concept question, How can we help plants grow?
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Engage in conversations with a variety of partners, taking turns listening and speaking.
Respond appropriately to spoken language.
Understand and use a growing number of relational words; Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Talk and share
Make connections between situations.
Join two or more words to create a compound word.
Share and repeat the details in a text.
Revise and edit group writing.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Challenge students to compare objects or describe their spatial relationship.
Guide students to understand that words can help them express connections.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we help plants grow?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Which book do you like better? Why?
Pretend you are a sunflower drying up and about to drop its seeds. Show me what you will do.
Could you count all the seeds in one sunflower? Why or why not?
What are you writing about? Could you think of another detail to add?
Imagine a leaf as a little kitchen making food for the rest of the plant. How would you draw that or make a model of it?
Can you put the two words tree and top together to make a bigger word? What does that word mean? How is that like the top of the magic beanstalk?
What do you think would happen if you switched these two parts?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Seed to Plant by Lisa M. Herrington. Copyright © 2014 by Scholastic Inc. Published by Scholastic Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to introduce vocabulary (center, scatter).
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking, What do sunflowers need to grow healthy and strong?
Read interactively for physical engagement and imagination.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Engage in conversations with a variety of partners, taking turns listening and speaking.
Respond appropriately to spoken language.
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Talk and share
Make connections between situations.
Distinguish between letters, words, and pictures.
Share and repeat details in a text.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the relationship between plants and animals and their environments.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt, What kind of plant would you like to grow? Why?
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we help plants grow?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: If you wrote a book about plants, what would go in it?
Pretend to be your favorite plant. Show me how you grow.
How would you make plant food? What should go in it?
Pretend to be a flower and write a story about yourself. Tell me how it starts.
Imagine the most beautiful flower in the world. How would you make it?
Make up a name for a new plant. What letter does it start with?
Build something that a beanstalk could climb and grow on.

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Seed to Plant by Lisa M. Herrington. Copyright © 2014 by Scholastic Inc. Published by Scholastic Inc.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Engage in conversations in appropriate ways.
Show understanding by responding appropriately.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Talk and share.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Engage in prereading and reading-related activities.
Describe life cycles of organisms.
Observe, investigate, describe and discuss the relationship of organisms to their environments.
Engage in conversations in appropriate ways.
Show understanding by responding appropriately.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Talk and share.
Make connections between situations.
Engage in prereading and reading-related activities.
Combine words to make a compound word.
Interact and provide suggestions to revise (add, take out, change order) and edit (conventions) class-made drafts.
Describe life cycles of organisms.
Engage in conversations in appropriate ways.
Show understanding by responding appropriately.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe things.
Increase listening vocabulary and begin to develop vocabulary of object names and common phrases in English (ELL).
Talk and share.
Make connections between situations.
Make inferences and predictions about text.
Interact and provide suggestions to revise (add, take out, change order) and edit (conventions) class-made drafts.
Engage in conversations in appropriate ways.
Show understanding by responding appropriately.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Talk and share.
Make connections between situations.
Combine words to make a compound word.
Retell or reenact a story after it is read-aloud.
Interact and provide suggestions to revise (add, take out, change order) and edit (conventions) class-made drafts.
Engage in conversations in appropriate ways.
Show understanding by responding appropriately.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Talk and share.
Make connections between situations.
Can distinguish between elements of print including letters, words, and pictures.
Retell or reenact a story after it is read-aloud.
Observe, investigate, describe and discuss the relationship of organisms to their environments.
